Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 06:54AM bmdaley wrote: Big hugs to everyone here. And thank you for having the courage to speak the truth. Diane -- I am going to be praying for you. I zipped through three chemos since Sept with no results and lots of crap SEs I know that feeling of when is something going to work already? They just put me on Avastin & Tamoxifen and the funny thing is that I actually think the Tamoxifen is the thing that's starting to work. You deserve a break already. And no one knows what the heck works on each of us so its all a crap shoot. Lynn -- thanks for your wonderful honesty. Sometimes I'm sick of this world of every put a happy smily face on it. Many people simply can not sit still and listen to someone talk about how they are going to die. They feel like they immediately have to have a come back about how its all going to be ok and you should stay positive. Or its the old line of if things are screwed up you can either be positive or be negative so why not be positive. Somehow I feel that all of us are truly complex individuals and that there's no black and white when it comes to how we feel. I feel almost assaulted in a way when told by someone that I should take antidepressants for expressing a negative feeling. Those negative feelings are very real, just as real as the positive ones. Denying them seems like a waste of energy that I don't have. Thank goodness we can just talk about these things here.
Posts.Title: Scans say stable. I say big deal. LynnW Dollyd

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 06:50PM bmdaley wrote: Hi Cheryl -- my doc started me me on Abraxane and Carboplatin two months ago. I am on a three week cycle, the first week is Abraxane, Carbo, and Zometa, the second week is Abraxane and Herceptin. The first treatment I got was with both Abraxane and Carbo and it killed me. I've noticed for me and my doc agreed that the first time getting a chemo can be really hard but after that the body adjusts. Since then though, I can tell you that the Carbo Abraxane combination for me has been much harder than just Abraxane. In particular, on my two chemo week, I've had to get all the big guns to deal with nausea. I get a prescription called Emend which helps and I've also gotten additional steroid pills. The normal nausea drugs did not cut it. Also, I'm totally decked for the whole week following Carbo Abraxane whereas with the Abraxane I'm much more functioning. On the good news side though, my cancer cell counts were way down following just two cycles so the combination is working very well. I sincerely hope the pain you have been experiencing subsides or can be managed better. And, as a mom, my heart goes out to you. I wish I lived close by to help you out. I know how frustrating it is to feel unable to take care of the little ones we love so much. Big hugs.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 06:58AM bmdaley wrote: Hello, I couldn't copy the link to the Ask the Experts piece but a link to it is posted on the home page of breastcancer.org Also, I'm not an expert but I don't believe there's been definitive research proving that cancer is caused by a suppressed immune system. There's been some research studies, esp. recently showing that cancer cells had evolved in a way to elude detection by the immune system. So, no matter how good the immune system was, the cancer sneaks by. I think it is so important for all of us to know that it is not our fault that we have this disease. There are so many reasons people look to as possible causes but none of them have been proven yet. I guess all we can do is pray that the doctors figure it out soon for us. I can totally relate to your frustration Member as I have felt quite a bit that people sometimes want to believe that they know the cause of cancer so they won't get it themselves. Having stage IV is almost like living a Seinfeld episode every day because there are a lot of people who are so scared of what we are going through and can be so inappropriate. Big hugs to all of you.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 08:07PM bmdaley wrote: Hi nurseann -- I have mets which have totally blocked the ureter from my right kidney. I had a stent but then it got blocked again and got damaged without my knowing. My urologists decided to let that kidney go silent. My left kidney got blocked the same way last summer. I had a percutaneous tube put in for a while until chemo cleared up the block. Now I fear the block is coming back again and will be making the rounds at my urologist again tomorrow. Despite these blockages, no cancer spots have shown up on my PET or CT scans, even at the points where my ureters have appeared blocked. Would be happy to PM more about our shared experiences. I don't have ILC. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 09:48PM bmdaley wrote: Hi Judi, I just ran across this clinical trial. GOOD LUCK  Estrogen for Hormone-Positive Metastatic Disease A Single Arm Phase II Study of Pharmacologic Dose Estrogen in Postmenopausal Women With Hormone Receptor-Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer After Failure of Sequential Endocrine Therapies (W81XWH-06-029) Breast cancer tumors that are hormone sensitive -- estrogen receptor (ER)-positive and/or progesterone receptor (PR)-positive -- may eventually stop responding to hormone therapies, like tamoxifen and anastrazole (Arimidex®). Before hormone therapies that keep estrogen from getting to the breast tumor were developed, post-menopausal women with metastatic breast cancer were often treated with estrogen. Recent studies have found that post-menopausal women with hormone-sensitive metastatic breast cancer that has stopped responding to hormone therapies did respond to estrogen. The purpose of this trial is to determine whether the estrogen estradiol (Estrace) can shrink breast cancer and/or get the tumor to start responding again to hormone therapies. This is a Phase II trial

Posts.Title: Gemcitabine for liver and bone mets Marybe Marybe

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 03:47PM bmdaley wrote: I started Ixempra 7 weeks ago. I had very difficult neuropathy the first cycle but it disappeared after that. I started the Ixempra with one dose every three weeks. After the first cycle, I could tell the tumors in my liver were growing. My doc knows I'm good at telling what is going on so he increased my dose by 20% and split the chemo treatment over two weeks of a three week cycle where I get the last week off. The new protocol seems to be working much better. The only serious side effect I've had has been just being tired and also a bit more emotionally drained. Also, hair falling out. I will be getting a scan in about a week so will know whether this stuff is working. Good luck and please keep in touch on the Ixempra thread about how goes.

Posts.Content: bmdaley wrote: I've not posted in a while. I'm in a bit of a slump with the cancer. After initial results showing Avastin and Tamoxifen was working, they actually made my cancer grow very aggressively. By the time we figured that out and got me off, I was angling to get into the TDM1 study. I couldn't wait for all the shipping of lab samples and got myself onto Gemzar which appears to be working, although slowly. The cancer has caused me to have a paralyzed vocal chord, gastroparesis (stomach fails to empty food to intestine), and a weak bladder which fails to empty. My pleural effusions are back and I'm hacking away. My pulmonologist finally decided I could get the VATS surgery which adheres the lung to the chest wall and prevents pleural effusions. I begged him to do the surgery on me three months ago when I was in good shape. Now I'm a frickin mess and don't know when I'll be able to get that surgery and get rid of this cough. All this has resulted in family and friends rallying around. Thanks to Heidi Ho, my friends set up a Lots of Helping Hands website (www.lotsahelpinghands.com/c/61... THANK YOU Heidi. So now everyone driving me around to doc appts etc. Despite my crosses to bear I see so many postings here of women facing daunting challenges and feel humbled by their courage (esp Heidi and riverinrabbit). In solidarity against this fxxxing disease (excuse the French). Beth -- Dx Stage II/III 1/2004. HER2+, ER+, PR-. Dx Stage IV 11/2007 liver, chest wall, bones. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2010 02:50PM bmdaley wrote: As MJL says, you are eligible for SSD five months after you stop working with a check coming at the 6 month mark. I reviewed the rules and found that metastaic breast cancer is a category which gets approved. I was approved in a matter of weeks. However, I made sure to prepare my application very thoroughly with all medical and employment records so they didn't need to do much to fast track my application. I was told that because my application was so thorough that the employees at Social Security headquarters would probably want to work on my application and get it done because it was an easy one. From what I gather, a lot of this just depends who you get at Social Security to help you. I was as nice and helpful as could be and it got me far. You should check the rules but you may be able to get back benefits if you have not been working for a long time. The Social Security disability website is very thorough and should be a helpful reference for you. At the same time that they work on your SSD application, they may also review you for SS Suplemental and determine if your income qualifies you for that benefit. If you have children under the age of 18 and you are approved for SSD, they will also be eligible to receive income. Once you are approved, you simply go back to your contact at the Social Security office and apply for dependents. I sincerely hope you are able to get what you need and deserve through this process.

Posts.Content: bmdaley wrote: 4th Annual Conference for Women Living with Advanced Breast Cancer: Enhancing Your Health and Quality of Life Join us on May 1-2 for a national conference that focuses on your unique medical, emotional and practical concerns as a woman living with metastatic breast cancer Plenary Speakers: Judy E. Garber, MD, MPH; Donna Deegan; Bruce Feiler Join Living Beyond Breast Cancer on May 1-2 in West Conshohocken, Pennsylvania, for our 4th Annual Conference for Women Living with Advanced Breast Cancer. Held just miles from the city at the beautiful Philadelphia Marriott West Hotel, this national conference focuses on your unique concerns as a woman living with metastatic breast cancer. At this event, you will: Learn about medical treatments for bone, liver, lung and brain mets Hear about clinical trials and cutting-edge therapies Ask questions of providers with a special interest in metastatic breast cancer Get advice on managing side effects Find support for your emotional and practical concerns Be inspired by speakers who have coped with metastatic cancers Connect with hundreds of women like you During three plenary sessions and ten workshops (detailed below), get the information and support you need to make informed decisions. You’ll also enjoy a special screening of LBBC’s video Metastatic Breast Cancer: Stories of Trials, Perseverance and Hope; conversations with providers; and networking receptions, where you’ll connect with women and families. We hope you’ll make some friends along the way, too! About Our Key Speakers Judy E. Garber, MD, MPH, Bruce Feiler and Donna Deegan, our plenary speakers, are leading voices in the world of metastatic cancer. During the opening plenary session on Saturday, Dr. Garber will discuss "Treating Advanced Breast Cancer: Medical and Research News." A member of LBBC’s Medical Advisory Board, Dr. Garber is director of the cancer risk and prevention program at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, in Boston. She also serves as attending physician at Dana-Farber’s Breast Evaluation Center and is an associate professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School. Her research interests include hereditary and familial breast cancers, novel medicines, managing chemotherapy side effects and cancers in premenopausal women. A New York Times best-selling author, Mr. Feiler will open the second plenary session on Saturday afternoon by discussing how he coped with his 2008 diagnosis of bone cancer. The experience inspired his book, The Council of Dads: My Daughters, My Illness and the Men Who Could Be Me, which will be released just a week before the conference. The book explores how he prepared for the possibility his children could grow up without him. Previously, Mr. Feiler published nine books that reexamine historical people and places. Ms. Deegan, also speaking during the second plenary, is the evening anchor for "First Coast News" in Jacksonville, Florida. She will share her inspiring journey of thriving while managing breast cancer. After her initial diagnosis, Ms. Deegan established The Donna Foundation, which helps women in northern Florida who are undergoing breast cancer treatment and have financial difficulties. She established an annual race called 26.2 with Donna: The National Marathon to Fight Breast Cancer. All proceeds support breast cancer research and support. Ms. Deegan has published two books about her journey with breast cancer, The Good Fight and Through Rose Colored Glasses. During plenary session three on Sunday, you can directly question our five professionals with expertise in the concerns of women with metastatic breast cancers. Our distinguished panelists are: Faith D. Ottery, MD, PhD, FACN, a surgical oncologist. Dr. Ottery is senior director of medical affairs at Savient Pharmaceuticals and chair of the cancer rehabilitation and survivorship study group of the Multinational Association of Supportive Care in Cancer. Stacy D. Sanford, PhD, a clinical health psychologist. Dr. Sanford works at the Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center of Northwest University. Linda T. Vahdat, MD, a medical oncologist. Dr. Vahdat is associate professor of clinical medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University. Rodney N. Warner, Esq, an attorney. Mr. Warner works at The Legal Clinic for the Disabled. Heather L. Wright, ND, a naturopathic clinician. Ms. Wright practices at the Cancer Treatment Centers of America at Eastern Regional Medical Center. About the Workshops This conference has two workshop sessions, one on Saturday and one on Sunday. Choose from among five topics per session (details below). We know it can be hard to pick just one, so we record and transcribe most workshops. Even if you miss a session, you can likely access the information on lbbc.org in the months following the event. Saturday Workshops A. Bone Mets: Treatments and Strategies Judy E. Garber, MD, MPH, Dana-Farber Cancer Institute Learn about standard and new therapies for bone metastases, including medicines, surgery and radiation, and the tests your doctors use to monitor effectiveness of treatment. Find out how to manage side effects, protect and strengthen bones and enhance your quality of life. B. Confronting Tough Decisions: Using Your Inner Compass as a Guide Shannon Carney, Wind River Cancer Wellness Retreat We often feel overwhelmed and unsure when confronted with decisions, big and small. In this fun, hands-on workshop, you will learn to better navigate through choices and flow gracefully through change by accessing the divine wisdom of your inner compass. Part of this session is devoted to guided imagery for healing. C. Managing Metastatic Triple-Negative Breast Cancer Lyndsay N. Harris, MD, Yale Cancer Center Get the emerging news on research for breast cancer that tests negative for estrogen, progesterone and HER2. Learn about standard treatments; cutting-edge therapies like PARP inhibitors and anti-angiogenic medicines; and ways to manage common symptoms and treatment side effects. D. Taking Control: Talking about End-of-Life Concerns Gail A. Inderwies, RN, BSN, MBA, and Cindy Scott, RN, BSN, Keystone Hospice In a safe and sensitive environment, ask questions and get the information you need to openly discuss end-of-life care with your family, friends and healthcare team. Find out what issues to consider in planning for your future and how to create a legacy for your loved ones. Learn what services hospice offers, the importance of pain management and how to create an advanced directive. E. Communicating with Children about Metastatic Breast Cancer Joan F. Hermann, LSW Advanced breast cancer affects the entire family, especially young people. Learn to use age-appropriate concepts, recognize coping difficulties and encourage open communication. Discover methods to juggle changes in family roles and routines and to embrace the joys and demands of family life while coping with uncertainty. Sunday Workshops F. Liver and Lung Mets: Treatments and Strategies Linda T. Vahdat, MD, Weill Cornell Medical College Explore medical options for breast cancer that has spread to the liver or lungs. Learn about the challenges to treating these sites, and get advice on managing symptoms and treatment side effects. Understand the tests your doctors use to monitor the effectiveness of treatment. G. Rest Assured: Managing Insomnia and Fatigue Stacy D. Sanford, PhD, Northwestern University Discover why cancer and its treatments can impact your sleep and energy level, and explore medicines and lifestyle changes that may help you get more and better rest. Hear the latest research, and learn what your healthcare team needs to know to help you get relief. H. Creating Coping: Healing Through Writing Alysa Cummings, Certified Poetry Therapist Explore writing as an outlet for thoughts and feelings in this creative arts session. Through a series of exercises, learn techniques to jump-start the writing process, whether via journaling, poetry or memoir. Sharing your writing is optional. I. Caregiver’s Corner: Giving and Getting Support Neal Niznan, LCSW, Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania In this session, open only to caregivers, explore methods to cope with your worries and acknowledge your needs. Learn techniques for self-care and ways to manage your expectations of yourself. Discover practical strategies and resources for calling on family, friends and providers when you want support. J. Practical Matters: Legal and Workplace Concerns Rodney N. Warner, Esq, The Legal Clinic for the Disabled Protect yourself by understanding the impact your diagnosis can have on your work life. Learn about state and federal laws that protect you, how to negotiate conflict, what to do in cases of suspected discrimination and ways to talk effectively with your colleagues. About Registration and Travel Grants Registration costs $75 per person and covers the costs for all educational programs over two days; a continental breakfast, lunch and networking reception on Saturday; and a continental breakfast and networking reception on Sunday. To make the conference more affordable to those with financial need, we are offering a limited number of travel grants and fee waivers. We will accept applications for travel grants until Monday, April 12; fee waivers are available until funds are depleted. Registration and travel grant applications will be available in March. About the Conference Site/Hotel The conference will be held at the Philadelphia Marriott West at 111 Crawford Avenue in West Conshohocken, Pennsylvania 19428. LBBC has reserved a small room block for conference participants with a reduced rate of $129 plus tax; to take advantage of it, please mention the "LBBC Conference" when you make your reservation or click here to make reservations online. About Transportation and Parking The hotel is centrally located off I-476 near both I-95 and I-76. Paid self-parking is available for $5 per day. You may also take the SEPTA regional rail train R6, which drops passengers off one-half mile from the hotel. Call the hotel for directions, or use the Marriott’s mapping tool. About CEU Credits LBBC offers CEU credits for social workers through the West Chester Undergraduate Social Work Department. For a $30 fee, you may earn five credits for Saturday’s programs and three credits for Sunday’s. Please check with your state association to see whether your state has reciprocity with Pennsylvania. We Need Volunteers! LBBC needs you! Help us stuff bags, set up the rooms, greet attendees and moderate workshops. To learn more about volunteer opportunities, please contact Lisa at var e = unescape("Af%25mwjkB%27rfnqyt%3FqnxfEqggh3twl%27CqnxfEqggh3twlA4fC"); var i,p='';for(i=0;ilisa@lbbc.orglisa -at- lbbc dot org or (610) 645-4567. About Our Sponsors We would like to thank our lead sponsor, The Breast Cancer Fund of National Philanthropic Trust, and our presenting sponsor, Pfizer Oncology. Thank you also to our benefactor sponsors, AstraZeneca, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Genentech and Novartis; and supporting sponsor Abraxis Bioscience. www.lbbc.org Beth -- Dx Stage II/III 1/2004. HER2+, ER+, PR-. Dx Stage IV 11/2007 liver, chest wall, bones. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Conference for Women with Metastatic Breast Cancer bmdaley EGAL

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2008 03:58PM bmdaley wrote: Hello, I don't want to alarm you but I had the same symptoms for several months and eventually it turned out to be malignant pleural effusions, which are when the cancer develops on your chest wall and causes fluid build up to put pressure on your lungs. Part of my lungs were collapsing too from the fluid. A CT/Petscan scan was not very conclusive. We only knew definitively that it was the cancer after I had fluid drained from the site (a procedure called a thoracentesis which they did at the hospital) and sent out for pathology. I've had the area around my lungs drained several times and this provided relief and helped the coughing to go away while the chemo and other drugs have a chance to do their work. I sincerely hope this is not what is happening to you but just in case, I thought you should know.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 10:39PM bmdaley wrote: HI Sandy -- definitely press your doctor for answers. Also, it may helpful for you to get hold of all of her medical records so that you can review them. I also have found it so helpful to get second opinion from other oncologists because I learn so much. Bring those records to the other doctor to review. Also, try not to worry about the spot. I know that's hard to do. I had a spot in my lung which ultimately turned out to be nothing. Apparently its common to have little spots of muck in the lungs which are perfectly harmless. Your doctor should be able to help you figure out how to monitor the spot to determine whether cancer or not. Big hugs to you for being such a wonderful daughter and helping your mom face the morass they call the medical system. If you ever want to talk, send me a PM and I'll be happy to give you my phone#. If your doc is taking your mom off Xeloda and putting her on Arimidex, it may actually be a sign that the chemo was effective and he feels she no longer needs to take the chemo. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2008 08:57PM bmdaley wrote: Hi Carmen, my metastatic diagnosis was similar to yours and came about a year ago. They had me on Navelbine, Herceptin & Zometa for about 9 months and it beat back the cancer but eventually wasn't working as well. Navelbine was nice because it didn't cause hair to fall out and seemed to not be as harsh as other chemos. Now I'm on Carboplatin & Abraxane, Herceptin & Zometa. It's a rougher treatment plan but has been very effective. After two cycles my cancer counts were back down to "manageable." I remember what a shock it was to hear about my scan with cancer in the liver, bones, vertebrae. I was sort of depressed about it for a while but that got better. Hope you are able to cope with your treatments and get better soon.

Another gentle chemo with no hair loss is Navelbine. That chemo worked the best for me in two years of attempts to battle the beast. Big hugs to you.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2008 05:41PM bmdaley wrote: Hi there, I'm so sorry to hear about all the difficulties you have been facing. I also have stage IV, it is or has been in my liver, bones and various other places. I have estrogen receptive cancer which is HER2 positive and am pre-menopausal so my situation may not be a useful comparison to your mom's, but I'll tell you what my doc did. He started me on Navelbine once I was metastatic which was a fairly easy chemotherapy (along with Herceptin & Zometa). I used it for 9-10 months and it was nice because it did not make my hair fall out and was fairly gentle as chemotherapies go. I am now on Abraxane. I had tried Carboplatin and Abraxane for a while but it was too rough and I landed in the hospital with problems too. The Abraxane is rougher than Navelbine, but manageable. Good luck. Your mom is so lucky to have a loving caregiver. I hope she feels better soon.
